review:
Overwatch 2 is an excellent game that encompasses all the critical aspects that make for an enjoyable gaming experience. The art design is top-notch with an almost Pixar look to it. The sound design provides great synchronous feedback for each weapon used, and the music is perfectly themed to each setting. The maps are well-thought-out and include beautiful destinations from around the world. The game modes are the typical ones you'd see in any other online shooter. The large roster of characters each has their own unique costumes and personalities.

Consensus:

While I would definitely rank Overwatch 2 above many other popular shooters and recommend it to others, I would also be hesitant to invest a significant amount of time in it. The reason for this is consistency. If you've played the original Overwatch and then transitioned to Overwatch 2, somewhere during the transition, consistency was lost. The overhaul changed small details that made the original Overwatch's gunplay streamlined and fun.

Scout: This game sucks ass, how did you find out about it?
Spy: Pornography
At this point just play Paladins

æš´é›ªæˆ‘cä½ mï¼Œä½ å°±è·Ÿä¸ªshiä¸€æ ·ï¼Œè€å­æ¢ç€å·ç»™ä½ åˆ·å·®è¯„ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰biè„¸å›æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘cä½ mæˆ‘ä¸€å¤©çœ‹ä¸åˆ°ä½ ç™¾åˆ†ç™¾å·®è¯„æˆ‘å°±éš¾å—
ä½ è¯´å¾—å¯¹ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯Overwatch has encountered a critical error during startup. Please reinstall the game and try again.

[h1] Overwatch 2 is a game that does not deserve your time or money [/h1]

Overwatch 2 is a shell of its former self, fallen to the predatory freemium models of the modern gaming industry, with all the bells and whistles of false corporate promises and constant let downs. The initial release of OW2 was something to be excited about as the slow decline of meaningful updates to the original Overwatch were wearing thin on the community but most held on to hope as we knew that the majority of resources was being poured into the sequal that would save the IP. When OW2 released it was a bit of a shock to see that all that had been added was 3 heros, 1 game mode and a handful of maps, and of course the dreaded store page and battlepass. Yet the community still held on hope for the PvE that we had heard so much about, the corner stone of the reason as to why a second Overwatch was needed, but then it happened.
The Overwatch development team announced, that they would not be able to bring the PvE mode that they had originally added, as the scope of their ambitions was ''too big'' for the time frame and resources that they had. Yet they had been moving all of the resources of the Overwatch 1 team to work on this. They had spent 5 YEARS neglecting their already successful game to release a sorry excuse for a sequel, a glorified update, that consisted of 3 heros, 1 gamemode and a few maps, all the while removing many features that had no need to be removed. 5 years spent on the now known 'store update'. From this OW2 has gone downhill fast, plauged with poor updates, abysmal matchmaking and terrible game balance, stemming (from my opinion) the removal of 1 tank, trying to rebalance a set of characters created for a 6v6 format into a new 5v5 format was always going to have issues, but the team has not been able to rectify this to any degree.

Overwatch 2 is a pitiful excuse for a video game sequel and does not deserve any of your time or money, because god knows if we let them they will make an Overwatch 3 and it will be just as disapointing

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The game is a good game, but the company is like a pile of shit

[h1] IMPORTANT DISCLAIMERS AND INFO: [/h1]
1. The reason this games reviews are so negative is because of a combined effort using bots and trolls by another community, THEY ARE NOT LEGITIMATE.
2. ATOW It says I have 5 hours, but If i'm remembering correctly, I have about 400 or so hours in this game as I played before it came to steam.

[b] IF YOU WANT A TLDR, SCROLL TO THE BOTTOM! THIS REVIEW IS A BIT LONG! [/b]

Now, my actual Review
Setting Petty, pointless video game rivalries aside, Overwatch 2 is an, in my honest opinion, at its fundamental core one of the best team shooters.

To immediately address it, yes blizzard is not a great company. Yes, the game's monetization is aggressive and at times very questionable, but I have a few things to say about these before I continue that I hope can, not make you excuse them entirely, but at least go a bit easier on the game itself.

[h1] Obligatory monetization discussion [/h1]
First of all, the only paywall'd content that truly matters and really impacts gameplay is Heroes, and well yes, you may get them sooner by buying it, You can unlock new heroes in the free battle pass with a little bit of grinding. And, by the next season, heroes are made available for everyone who does not have them to unlock via meeting specific requirements while playing games (Typically queuing for every role in the role queue mode, which is quite easy and should not be too disruptive to a players experience). Yes it is kind of shitty that you can pay to get heroes a bit faster then other people, but the fact you can unlock them, at least for me kind of allows this to be slightly excused. Not fully, or even alot, just...slightly, and if you really think about it, things like this have been done by games both similar and dissimilar to OW2 many times in the past, INCLUDING the weapons in a certain """""""""""Similar"""""""""""" game I won't mention here.

That aside, again, I don't exactly like blizzard as a company either. But I play, and monetarily support this game because of not only my love for the core game independent of its parent company itself, but also for my love of team 4. Please remember team 4 (The team that works on Overwatch), is not to blame for a single major thing that's gone wrong with this game. Direct all your hate at ActiBlizz corpa.

Now that that's out of the way, I can finally ACTUALLY talk about gameplay & stuff.

[h1] Experience & PVP Gameplay! [/h1]

 To get something out of the way immediately, on boot this game offers a tutorial, which, as much as that may seem like a really simple thing, like "Duh, what game, especially a complex team shooter, wouldn't have a tutorial for first timers?", You'd be surprised how a lot of games don't, or have it shafted off to the side and/or also have it be really bad. (COUGH COUGH...) This game's tutorial immediately arms you with pretty much everything you need to know in a concise, helpful, and good way.

Moving on from that, you're greeted with the menus. This game's menus impressed me the first time I fired up the game, from the stunning art, to the amazingly composed music, and simply their sleek, efficient design, they offer a very fun, yet also intuitive user interface.

The practice range is something every game like this should have. An area you're free to practice your aim, and learn about different heroes, this is a gold standard for games that have rosters of different characters, or different weapons or equipment the player may want to get a feel for first before going into a game.

Going into this, I've dragged on for long enough that i'll keep this short, but know that there's so much more depth to this games PVP combat and team play then I can cover here.

Overwatch's core gameplay revolves around [strike] 6v6 [/strike] 5v5 Team based FPS combat, centered around fighting for objectives in most game-modes. Having such a wide roster of heroes can seem intimidating at first, but as you grow to learn the game, and a hero or two, you'll quickly appreciate the variety, as they can allow you and your team to adapt to the map, game-mode, or the enemy's team composition, and with each of them being unique characters all with interesting designs, stories, and personalities, beyond this also having unique and interesting sets of moves and game-play loops, Each hero's kit, for the most part feels responsive, delicately put together, and most importantly, fun to use.

Most of Overwatch's gamemode's are quite standard, but when Overwatch innovates, it does so very well, whether its as simple as hybrid, a combination of attack/defense and payload, or as unique as Push, a tug of war style gamemode where teams fight for control of a robot in the aim to push their barricade a further distance into the enemy teams territory.

Ultimate abilities in this game are an engaging, fun mechanic! Nothing feels better then being rewarded for your effort and skill, with a strong, impactful ability accompanied with a iconic character and POV unique line, to help you and your team defeat your enemy's in style! These lines, the visual and gameplay effects of the ultimate also make them a shocking and always fun experience to learn to memorize and decide with your team how best to handle the situation of one!

[h1] World & Characters [/h1]
Overwatch is set in an optimistic future around the year 2070 (If I remember correctly), That will bring anybody with a hope for a good future of humanity a wide smile, Overwatch aims to create a world worth fighting the sudden threat of null sector, and in this it succeeds.

Even beyond this diverse world you get to travel all across, and fight for, you have the characters. Every hero in this game has their own unique, intriguing backstory and fun, lovable personalities and visual designs. They come from all over the world, different places, reminding you of the beautiful diverse world we live in, through their variety of backgrounds, sexuality, and other traits!

[h1] My closing thoughts (And why you should try it, if I still haven't convinced you) [/h1]
Overwatch not only has built a riveting world of riveting characters, but also an amazing team game, that exemplifies the great feeling of teamwork, and provides an enjoyable shooter experience. If that is what you're looking for, or if you have negative perceptions of Overwatch and have not tried it, especially if you enjoy similar games, all I ask is you clear your mind and give it an honest try. It is a free game, and all you will lose for trying it is a bit of your time if you do not like it, but I promise, i'm quite sure you will.

[h1]From Hero to Zero[/h1]

The year is 2019. Blizzcon was happening from November 1st to 2nd. Overwatch had been out for around 3 and a half years at that time. The Overwatch dev team finally unveiled the sequel (Overwatch 2) to the current game at the time, with the "Zero Hour" announcement trailer. Alongside this, we would also get a new PvE mode with Hero Talents and skills - aswell as a story mode seperate from the PvP-oriented playstyle of the game, just as showcased live during the event. This was what also made Overwatch 2 the main selling point - the whole community was hyped.

Fast forward the clock to April 2021, and the lead director of Overwatch, Jeff Kaplan leaves Blizzard after 19 years, with Aaron Keller to take over his role as the lead director of the game. And ever since then, Overwatch has gone downhill from there, from the harassment scandal at Blizzard to killing OW1 for 2, with no ups to compensate for. And then the scrapping of the vision of the PvE we had back in 2019 to top it off?

Let me give my personal insight of this game. Like many other people, I picked up this game around November 2016 - albeit a few months after it launched. Loved it for the first few years - fun game to play around with friends, and even by solo at times. I had stopped constantly playing this game around 2018 but decided to pick it up again around Jan 2021, been playing it here and off since. And then in May 2023, I finally stopped playing the game after like 500-600(?) hours into the game, with the exception of a few minutes recently so I can leave a review.

This is not the Overwatch I loved anymore. This is basically a [u]stripped-down[/u] version of the original game - the original game (that at least had integrity and soul, and even a [i]solid[/i] loot box system) was killed off in favor of this soulless, microtransactions-filled garbage with a [u]strictly[/u] inferior monetization system (premium battle pass you literally [b]have[/b] to pay for, instead of free loot boxes) that even locks new heroes behind it.

At that point, the only hope I had left for the game was the vision of the PvE from 2019 they had promised for. And then they announced they basically took [b]ALL[/b] of that away from it - basically the [b]WHOLE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ SELLING POINT OF THE GAME[/b] - even before the moment of the game's absolutely disastrous launch (this was also the moment I stopped playing the game). Oh wait, later they revealed a new vision of the PvE for the game... basically just glorified Archives missions (that were actually good, not gonna lie)... but now that's [b]ALSO[/b] gonna be locked behind the premium battle pass a.k.a. a paywall? And only for the first [i]three[/i] missions? Wow, no wonder Jeff Kaplan left...

[i]Police Officer: Does this mean... Overwatch is back?[/i]

[i]Winston: No.[/i]
